summary:
Animation Monday: How Animators Created The Spider-Verse

Loved Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse?  You'll love the...
caption:
Animation Monday: How Animators Created The Spider-Verse

Loved Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse?  You’ll love the behind-the-scenes to see how this movie was animated!  WIRED went and interviewed Danny Dimian, Visual Effects Supervisor, and Josh Beveridge, Head of Character Animation, for “Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse."  They share exclusive breakdowns and talk about their inspiration and the techniques they used to create a new visual language for their Academy Award-winning film.  See it below!

tags: dont know where this came from
we do need more interaction between pepper and peter
this is trash and im sorry
summary: You know what we need? Some Pepper Potts and Peter Parker interaction.
question: You know what we need? Some Pepper Potts and Peter Parker interaction.
answer:
Pepper slipped into the house quietly. It was well past 9pm and she had been stuck at work all day. She hated these days. She missed her family terribly when she had to be away from them for so long. She hated missing bedtime and reading Morgan a story as she rocked her to sleep.

As soon as she slipped off her heels, she headed straight upstairs. Her first stop was their bedroom, but Tony wasn’t there. She wandered out and across the hall to Morgan’s room. She had expected to find Morgan and Tony asleep in the rocking chair. Instead she found Morgan asleep against Peter and Peter looked too scared to move.

Pepper walked over and placed a hand on Peter’s shoulder. She smiled at him softly and he looked up at her. Partially relieved and partially like he was afraid she might wake Morgan. It must have been a rough night trying to get the baby to sleep.

“I can take her,” She whispered to Peter.

Peter shook his head, “she just fell asleep.”

Pepper nodded and moved to sit down on the foot rest in front of the rocking chair. God, she was exhausted.

“Thank you for doing this, Peter. It’s a huge help. Where’s Tony?”

“In the workshop fixing Rhodey’s suit,” Peter responded.

Pepper nodded and let her eyes fall shut for just a moment. She would go wrangle up her husband soon and make him come to bed.

“I was going to help him, but then Morgan woke up and she was crying for you and he couldn’t get her to calm down, so I brought her up here to give it a try.”

Pepper peeked over at her sleeping daughter, “looks like it worked. She loves you.”

Peter’s smile lit up his whole face, “you think so?”

“Of course. You’re like her big brother.”

Peter looked down at the sleeping baby. He was like her big brother. He loved her and he would do anything to protect her.

Pepper stood and gently took Morgan from Peter. She held the baby close and kissed her forehead. Morgan opened her eyes and stared up at her mother, and for a second both Peter and Pepper held their breath, hoping she wouldn’t start screaming. They both looked relieved when she just snuggled closer to Pepper and fell right back to sleep.

“You have school tomorrow. You need to get some rest. Did you eat dinner and finish your homework?”

“I did all of that and I even studied for midterms,” he said proudly.

“Good. I’ve got it from here. You need to get home before your aunt starts to worry.”

“She had a date night with Happy.” Peter made a face that caused Pepper to chuckle. May and Happy had been dating for a while now, but Peter was still getting used to the idea.

Peter stood and kissed Morgan on the top of the head before moving to kiss Pepper on the cheek. Recently they had become very close. Pepper felt like she had been blessed with two children instead of just one.

“You work too hard,” Peter said.

“You’ve been spending too much time with Tony,” she said with a sigh. She knew they were both right every time they told her she was working too hard.

“He worries about you.”

“I know. Go say goodbye to him and do not get sucked into helping him.”

Peter headed out of the room and laughed quietly, “no promises!”

Pepper shook her head and sighed. She was happy that Peter had someone like Tony in his life, but sometimes Tony forgot that Peter was still a kid who needed to eat and sleep and do his homework. Sometimes she needed to put her foot down and get Peter home at a decent hour.

Pepper tucked Morgan into her crib and made her way to the workshop. She kissed her husband hello and made him stop working long enough to take Peter home for the night.

He would be back again tomorrow. He would sit at the kitchen table and do his homework. He would ask questions about it that he already knew the answer to, but wanted to make sure before he turned it in. Tony would go over his homework, because he cared enough to make sure Peter passed all his classes and did well in school. They would take Morgan from her high chair and try to teach her how to build robots. Pepper didn’t have the heart to tell them that Morgan hadn’t quite reached her stage of development where she cared about building robots.

Tomorrow, Pepper would be home in time to make a home cooked meal for both of them and she would not be missing bedtime a second day in a row. Tomorrow, she would overhear Peter telling Tony about the girl he likes, and she would have to interject when Tony tried to give him advice. Tomorrow, Peter would hug her and thank her for the helpful advice. Pepper would smirk at Tony and he would shrug his shoulders and drag Peter down to the workshop.

This was her family now; Tony, Morgan and Peter. This was her family and nothing made her happier than the three of them.

“You have school tomorrow. You need to get some rest. Did you eat dinner and finish your homework?”

“I did all of that and I even studied for midterms,” he said proudly.

“Good. I’ve got it from here. You need to get home before your aunt starts to worry.”

“She had a date night with Happy.” Peter made a face that caused Pepper to chuckle. May and Happy had been dating for a while now, but Peter was still getting used to the idea.

Peter stood and kissed Morgan on the top of the head before moving to kiss Pepper on the cheek. Recently they had become very close. Pepper felt like she had been blessed with two children instead of just one.

“You work too hard,” Peter said.

“You’ve been spending too much time with Tony,” she said with a sigh. She knew they were both right every time they told her she was working too hard.

“He worries about you.”

“I know. Go say goodbye to him and do not get sucked into helping him.”

Peter headed out of the room and laughed quietly, “no promises!”

Pepper shook her head and sighed. She was happy that Peter had someone like Tony in his life, but sometimes Tony forgot that Peter was still a kid who needed to eat and sleep and do his homework. Sometimes she needed to put her foot down and get Peter home at a decent hour.

Pepper tucked Morgan into her crib and made her way to the workshop. She kissed her husband hello and made him stop working long enough to take Peter home for the night.

He would be back again tomorrow. He would sit at the kitchen table and do his homework. He would ask questions about it that he already knew the answer to, but wanted to make sure before he turned it in. Tony would go over his homework, because he cared enough to make sure Peter passed all his classes and did well in school. They would take Morgan from her high chair and try to teach her how to build robots. Pepper didn’t have the heart to tell them that Morgan hadn’t quite reached her stage of development where she cared about building robots.

Tomorrow, Pepper would be home in time to make a home cooked meal for both of them and she would not be missing bedtime a second day in a row. Tomorrow, she would overhear Peter telling Tony about the girl he likes, and she would have to interject when Tony tried to give him advice. Tomorrow, Peter would hug her and thank her for the helpful advice. Pepper would smirk at Tony and he would shrug his shoulders and drag Peter down to the workshop.

This was her family now; Tony, Morgan and Peter. This was her family and nothing made her happier than the three of them.

Peter. P: There's only one thing worse then dying
